paving the way toward a future training paradigm where AI agents autonomously
monitor training logs, proactively resolve instabilities, and optimize training
dynamics.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Interactive Training, a framework enabling real-time intervention in neural network training.
AI.motivation: Traditional training methods lack flexibility to adjust to instabilities or emerging issues.
AI.method: Interactive Training involves a control server that mediates dynamic adjustments by users or automated agents during training.
AI.result: The framework achieves better training stability, lower sensitivity to initial settings, and enhanced adaptability.
AI.conclusion: Interactive Training allows dynamic intervention, setting a foundation for autonomous AI monitoring and optimization of training processes.

title: Transformers Discover Molecular Structure Without Graph Priors
summary:
Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) are the dominant architecture for molecular
machine learning, particularly for molecular property prediction and machine
learning interatomic potentials (MLIPs). GNNs perform message passing on
predefined graphs often induced by a fixed radius cutoff or k-nearest neighbor
scheme. While this design aligns with the locality present in many molecular
tasks, a hard-coded graph can limit expressivity due to the fixed receptive
field and slows down inference with sparse graph operations. In this work, we
investigate whether pure, unmodified Transformers trained directly on Cartesian
coordinates$\unicode{x2013}$without predefined graphs or physical
priors$\unicode{x2013}$can approximate molecular energies and forces. As a
starting point for our analysis, we demonstrate how to train a Transformer to
competitive energy and force mean absolute errors under a matched training
compute budget, relative to a state-of-the-art equivariant GNN on the OMol25
dataset. We discover that the Transformer learns physically consistent
patterns$\unicode{x2013}$such as attention weights that decay inversely with
interatomic distance$\unicode{x2013}$and flexibly adapts them across different
molecular environments due to the absence of hard-coded biases. The use of a
standard Transformer also unlocks predictable improvements with respect to
scaling training resources, consistent with empirical scaling laws observed in
other domains. Our results demonstrate that many favorable properties of GNNs
can emerge adaptively in Transformers, challenging the necessity of hard-coded
graph inductive biases and pointing toward standardized, scalable architectures
for molecular modeling.

AI.tldr: This paper examines whether Transformers, trained directly on Cartesian coordinates without predefined graphs or physical priors, can match the performance of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for molecular energy and force predictions.
AI.motivation: To address limitations of GNNs in molecular modeling, such as fixed receptive fields and slower inference, by exploring whether Transformers can serve as an alternative architecture without relying on predefined graphs.
AI.method: A standard Transformer model is trained on Cartesian coordinates and evaluated for molecular tasks under matched training compute budgets, compared against a state-of-the-art equivariant GNN using the OMol25 dataset.
AI.result: Transformers achieve competitive performance in molecular energy and force prediction, learning physically meaningful patterns such as attention decay with distance, and showing scalable improvements with increasing computational resources.
AI.conclusion: Transformers can adaptively acquire many properties advantageous for molecular tasks traditionally hard-coded into GNNs, offering a scalable and flexible alternative for molecular modeling.

title: How to Combat Reactive and Dynamic Jamming Attacks with Reinforcement Learning
summary:
This paper studies the problem of mitigating reactive jamming, where a jammer
adopts a dynamic policy of selecting channels and sensing thresholds to detect
and jam ongoing transmissions. The transmitter-receiver pair learns to avoid
jamming and optimize throughput over time (without prior knowledge of channel
conditions or jamming strategies) by using reinforcement learning (RL) to adapt
transmit power, modulation, and channel selection. Q-learning is employed for
discrete jamming-event states, while Deep Q-Networks (DQN) are employed for
continuous states based on received power. Through different reward functions
and action sets, the results show that RL can adapt rapidly to spectrum
dynamics and sustain high rates as channels and jamming policies change over
time.

AI.tldr: This study employs reinforcement learning (RL), including Q-learning and Deep Q-Networks (DQN), to counteract dynamic reactive jamming and optimize transmitter-receiver throughput.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of reactive jamming, where adversaries dynamically adjust strategies to disrupt communications, aiming to ensure effective and resilient data transmissions.
AI.method: The study uses reinforcement learning techniques, leveraging Q-learning for discrete states and Deep Q-Networks (DQN) for continuous power states. It optimizes transmission power, modulation, and channel choices in response to evolving channel and jamming dynamics.
AI.result: Simulation results demonstrate that RL methods effectively adapt to dynamic spectrum conditions and successfully maintain high throughput despite changing jamming policies.
AI.conclusion: Reinforcement learning proves useful in combating reactive jamming by enabling transmitters and receivers to adapt rapidly and sustain communication performance in volatile environments.

title: BioBlobs: Differentiable Graph Partitioning for Protein Representation Learning
summary:
Protein function is driven by coherent substructures which vary in size and
topology, yet current protein representation learning models (PRL) distort
these signals by relying on rigid substructures such as k-hop and fixed radius
neighbourhoods. We introduce BioBlobs, a plug-and-play, fully differentiable
module that represents proteins by dynamically partitioning structures into
flexibly-sized, non-overlapping substructures ("blobs"). The resulting blobs
are quantized into a shared and interpretable codebook, yielding a discrete
vocabulary of function-relevant protein substructures used to compute protein
embeddings. We show that BioBlobs representations improve the performance of
widely used protein encoders such as GVP-GNN across various PRL tasks. Our
approach highlights the value of architectures that directly capture
function-relevant protein substructures, enabling both improved predictive
performance and mechanistic insight into protein function.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces BioBlobs, a novel module for protein representation learning that dynamically partitions proteins into flexible substructures to improve prediction accuracy and interpretability.
AI.motivation: To address limitations in existing protein representation learning methods, which rely on rigid substructures that distort meaningful signals in protein function.
AI.method: BioBlobs dynamically partitions proteins into flexible, non-overlapping substructures ("blobs"), quantizes them into an interpretable codebook, and uses this discrete vocabulary for embedding, compatible with common protein encoders.
AI.result: Implementing BioBlobs improved the performance of protein encoders like GVP-GNN on various protein learning tasks.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic representation of protein substructures enhances predictive performance and provides deeper insights into protein function.

title: Diffusion^2: Turning 3D Environments into Radio Frequency Heatmaps
summary:
Modeling radio frequency (RF) signal propagation is essential for
understanding the environment, as RF signals offer valuable insights beyond the
capabilities of RGB cameras, which are limited by the visible-light spectrum,
lens coverage, and occlusions. It is also useful for supporting wireless
diagnosis, deployment, and optimization. However, accurately predicting RF
signals in complex environments remains a challenge due to interactions with
obstacles such as absorption and reflection. We introduce Diffusion^2, a
diffusion-based approach that uses 3D point clouds to model the propagation of
RF signals across a wide range of frequencies, from Wi-Fi to millimeter waves.
To effectively capture RF-related features from 3D data, we present the RF-3D
Encoder, which encapsulates the complexities of 3D geometry along with
signal-specific details. These features undergo multi-scale embedding to
simulate the actual RF signal dissemination process. Our evaluation, based on
synthetic and real-world measurements, demonstrates that Diffusion^2 accurately
estimates the behavior of RF signals in various frequency bands and
environmental conditions, with an error margin of just 1.9 dB and 27x faster
than existing methods, marking a significant advancement in the field. Refer to
https://rfvision-project.github.io/ for more information.

AI.tldr: This paper presents Diffusion^2, a diffusion-based approach using 3D point clouds to accurately model RF signal propagation with minimal error.
AI.motivation: Current methods for predicting RF signal propagation struggle with complex environments due to obstacles like absorption and reflection, limiting their utility.
AI.method: The proposed method, Diffusion^2, uses a novel RF-3D Encoder to extract RF-specific features from 3D point clouds, leveraging multi-scale embedding to model signal behavior effectively.
AI.result: Diffusion^2 achieves high accuracy in simulating RF signal dissemination across various conditions, with an error of 1.9 dB and operating 27x faster than existing approaches.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion^2 significantly advances the prediction of RF signal propagation, enabling faster and more accurate estimations in diverse environments and frequency ranges.

title: Towards Human-Centered RegTech: Unpacking Professionals' Strategies and Needs for Using LLMs Safely
summary:
Large Language Models are profoundly changing work patterns in high-risk
professional domains, yet their application also introduces severe and
underexplored compliance risks. To investigate this issue, we conducted
semi-structured interviews with 24 highly-skilled knowledge workers from
industries such as law, healthcare, and finance. The study found that these
experts are commonly concerned about sensitive information leakage,
intellectual property infringement, and uncertainty regarding the quality of
model outputs. In response, they spontaneously adopt various mitigation
strategies, such as actively distorting input data and limiting the details in
their prompts. However, the effectiveness of these spontaneous efforts is
limited due to a lack of specific compliance guidance and training for Large
Language Models. Our research reveals a significant gap between current NLP
tools and the actual compliance needs of experts. This paper positions these
valuable empirical findings as foundational work for building the next
generation of Human-Centered, Compliance-Driven Natural Language Processing for
Regulatory Technology (RegTech), providing a critical human-centered
perspective and design requirements for engineering NLP systems that can
proactively support expert compliance workflows.

AI.tldr: This paper studies how Large Language Models affect the work patterns of professionals in high-risk domains, revealing compliance concerns and limited mitigation strategies.
AI.motivation: Professionals in law, healthcare, and finance face compliance challenges while using Large Language Models, prompting a need to explore their risks and usage strategies.
AI.method: Researchers conducted semi-structured interviews with 24 highly-skilled knowledge workers across various industries.
AI.result: The study identified concerns like sensitive information leakage, intellectual property risks, and low confidence in model outputs. Experts use informal mitigation strategies, but these are largely ineffective due to a lack of guidance.
AI.conclusion: There's an urgent need for Human-Centered, Compliance-Driven NLP systems tailored to regulatory workflows, addressing gaps between existing tools and professional needs.

title: Fine-Grained Urban Traffic Forecasting on Metropolis-Scale Road Networks
summary:
Traffic forecasting on road networks is a complex task of significant
practical importance that has recently attracted considerable attention from
the machine learning community, with spatiotemporal graph neural networks
(GNNs) becoming the most popular approach. The proper evaluation of traffic
forecasting methods requires realistic datasets, but current publicly available
benchmarks have significant drawbacks, including the absence of information
about road connectivity for road graph construction, limited information about
road properties, and a relatively small number of road segments that falls
short of real-world applications. Further, current datasets mostly contain
information about intercity highways with sparsely located sensors, while city
road networks arguably present a more challenging forecasting task due to much
denser roads and more complex urban traffic patterns. In this work, we provide
a more complete, realistic, and challenging benchmark for traffic forecasting
by releasing datasets representing the road networks of two major cities, with
the largest containing almost 100,000 road segments (more than a 10-fold
increase relative to existing datasets). Our datasets contain rich road
features and provide fine-grained data about both traffic volume and traffic
speed, allowing for building more holistic traffic forecasting systems. We show
that most current implementations of neural spatiotemporal models for traffic
forecasting have problems scaling to datasets of our size. To overcome this
issue, we propose an alternative approach to neural traffic forecasting that
uses a GNN without a dedicated module for temporal sequence processing, thus
achieving much better scalability, while also demonstrating stronger
forecasting performance. We hope our datasets and modeling insights will serve
as a valuable resource for research in traffic forecasting.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a new benchmark for traffic forecasting by releasing large datasets with rich road features for urban road networks and proposes a scalable spatiotemporal model using GNN without a temporal sequence module.
AI.motivation: Current traffic forecasting datasets only cover sparsely located intercity highways, lack realistic urban road features, and fall short in scale compared to real-world scenarios.
AI.method: They developed large-scale datasets for two cities with detailed road features and presented a scalable GNN model for traffic prediction, omitting temporal sequence processing modules.
AI.result: The proposed GNN model demonstrated superior scalability and improved forecasting accuracy compared to existing neural spatiotemporal models.
AI.conclusion: Their datasets and modeling approach address limitations in current traffic forecasting benchmarks and provide valuable resources for future traffic prediction research.

title: Addressing Pitfalls in the Evaluation of Uncertainty Estimation Methods for Natural Language Generation
summary:
Hallucinations are a common issue that undermine the reliability of large
language models (LLMs). Recent studies have identified a specific subset of
hallucinations, known as confabulations, which arise due to predictive
uncertainty of LLMs. To detect confabulations, various methods for estimating
predictive uncertainty in natural language generation (NLG) have been
developed. These methods are typically evaluated by correlating uncertainty
estimates with the correctness of generated text, with question-answering (QA)
datasets serving as the standard benchmark. However, commonly used approximate
correctness functions have substantial disagreement between each other and,
consequently, in the ranking of the uncertainty estimation methods. This allows
one to inflate the apparent performance of uncertainty estimation methods. We
propose using several alternative risk indicators for risk correlation
experiments that improve robustness of empirical assessment of UE algorithms
for NLG. For QA tasks, we show that marginalizing over multiple LLM-as-a-judge
variants leads to reducing the evaluation biases. Furthermore, we explore
structured tasks as well as out of distribution and perturbation detection
tasks which provide robust and controllable risk indicators. Finally, we
propose to use an Elo rating of uncertainty estimation methods to give an
objective summarization over extensive evaluation settings.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses confabulation issues in large language models (a type of hallucination) caused by predictive uncertainty. It proposes methods to improve the evaluation robustness of uncertainty estimation algorithms by suggesting alternative risk indicators and advocating for Elo ratings.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to handle the problem of hallucinations in large language models, particularly confabulations, by addressing the limitations of current evaluation methods for predictive uncertainty.
AI.method: The authors propose alternative methods for evaluating uncertainty estimation in natural language generation. This includes using alternative risk indicators, marginalizing over multiple LLM-as-a-judge variants, exploring structured and out-of-distribution tasks, and applying Elo ratings to summarize performance across evaluations.
AI.result: The proposed risk indicators and marginalization methods improve the robustness of empirical assessments of uncertainty estimation algorithms. They reduce evaluation biases and make the assessment of LLM uncertainty more reliable.
AI.conclusion: The study concludes that using diverse risk indicators and Elo ratings provides a more objective and robust evaluation framework for assessing predictive uncertainty in LLMs, particularly in question-answering and beyond.

title: Knowledge Distillation Detection for Open-weights Models
summary:
We propose the task of knowledge distillation detection, which aims to
determine whether a student model has been distilled from a given teacher,
under a practical setting where only the student's weights and the teacher's
API are available. This problem is motivated by growing concerns about model
provenance and unauthorized replication through distillation. To address this
task, we introduce a model-agnostic framework that combines data-free input
synthesis and statistical score computation for detecting distillation. Our
approach is applicable to both classification and generative models.
Experiments on diverse architectures for image classification and text-to-image
generation show that our method improves detection accuracy over the strongest
baselines by 59.6% on CIFAR-10, 71.2% on ImageNet, and 20.0% for text-to-image
generation. The code is available at
https://github.com/shqii1j/distillation_detection.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a framework to detect whether a student model has been generated via knowledge distillation from a given teacher model, using only the student's weights and the teacher's API.
AI.motivation: Growing concerns about model provenance and unauthorized replication through knowledge distillation.
AI.method: A model-agnostic framework that combines data-free input synthesis with statistical score computation to detect knowledge distillation, applicable to both classification and generative models.
AI.result: Achieved substantial improvements in detection accuracy over baselines: 59.6% on CIFAR-10, 71.2% on ImageNet, and 20.0% for text-to-image generation.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method provides an effective solution for identifying student models distilled from teacher models, addressing issues of unauthorized replication.

title: Robust Tangent Space Estimation via Laplacian Eigenvector Gradient Orthogonalization
summary:
Estimating the tangent spaces of a data manifold is a fundamental problem in
data analysis. The standard approach, Local Principal Component Analysis
(LPCA), struggles in high-noise settings due to a critical trade-off in
choosing the neighborhood size. Selecting an optimal size requires prior
knowledge of the geometric and noise characteristics of the data that are often
unavailable. In this paper, we propose a spectral method, Laplacian Eigenvector
Gradient Orthogonalization (LEGO), that utilizes the global structure of the
data to guide local tangent space estimation. Instead of relying solely on
local neighborhoods, LEGO estimates the tangent space at each data point by
orthogonalizing the gradients of low-frequency eigenvectors of the graph
Laplacian. We provide two theoretical justifications of our method. First, a
differential geometric analysis on a tubular neighborhood of a manifold shows
that gradients of the low-frequency Laplacian eigenfunctions of the tube align
closely with the manifold's tangent bundle, while an eigenfunction with high
gradient in directions orthogonal to the manifold lie deeper in the spectrum.
Second, a random matrix theoretic analysis also demonstrates that low-frequency
eigenvectors are robust to sub-Gaussian noise. Through comprehensive
experiments, we demonstrate that LEGO yields tangent space estimates that are
significantly more robust to noise than those from LPCA, resulting in marked
improvements in downstream tasks such as manifold learning, boundary detection,
and local intrinsic dimension estimation.

AI.tldr: LEGO proposes a spectral method to robustly estimate tangent spaces on noisy data manifolds, outperforming traditional LPCA.
AI.motivation: Addressing the limitations of LPCA in high-noise environments due to its dependency on optimal neighborhood size.
AI.method: LEGO orthogonalizes gradients of low-frequency Laplacian eigenvectors instead of relying on local neighborhoods.
AI.result: LEGO achieves noise-robust tangent space estimates and improves manifold learning, boundary detection, and local dimension estimation.
AI.conclusion: LEGO leverages global data structure, overcoming the trade-offs faced by LPCA and enhancing robustness in manifold analysis tasks.

title: KaVa: Latent Reasoning via Compressed KV-Cache Distillation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) excel at multi-step reasoning problems with
explicit chain-of-thought (CoT), but verbose traces incur significant
computational costs and memory overhead, and often carry redundant, stylistic
artifacts. Latent reasoning has emerged as an efficient alternative that
internalizes the thought process, but it suffers from a critical lack of
supervision, limiting its effectiveness on complex, natural-language reasoning
traces. In this work, we propose KaVa, the first framework that bridges this
gap by distilling knowledge directly from a compressed KV-cache of the teacher
into a latent-reasoning student via self-distillation, leveraging the
representational flexibility of continuous latent tokens to align stepwise KV
trajectories. We show that the abstract, unstructured knowledge within
compressed KV-cache, which lacks direct token correspondence, can serve as a
rich supervisory signal for a latent reasoning student. Empirically, the
approach consistently outperforms strong latent baselines, exhibits markedly
smaller degradation from equation-only to natural-language traces, and scales
to larger backbones while preserving efficiency. These results establish
compressed KV-cache distillation as a scalable supervision signal for latent
reasoning, combining the accuracy of CoT-trained teachers with the efficiency
and deployability of latent inference.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces KaVa, a framework that uses compressed KV-cache self-distillation to enhance latent reasoning in LLMs, outperforming current baselines and achieving efficiency.
AI.motivation: Address the inefficiency and lack of supervision in latent reasoning for complex multi-step problems in large language models.
AI.method: KaVa distills knowledge from a compressed KV-cache of a teacher model into a latent-reasoning student using self-distillation and latent token alignment.
AI.result: KaVa outperforms latent baselines, retains accuracy for natural-language traces, scales to larger models, and improves efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Compressed KV-cache distillation is validated as an effective and scalable supervision signal for latent reasoning in LLMs.

title: Location Matters: Leveraging Multi-Resolution Geo-Embeddings for Housing Search
summary:
QuintoAndar Group is Latin America's largest housing platform,
revolutionizing property rentals and sales. Headquartered in Brazil, it
simplifies the housing process by eliminating paperwork and enhancing
accessibility for tenants, buyers, and landlords. With thousands of houses
available for each city, users struggle to find the ideal home. In this
context, location plays a pivotal role, as it significantly influences property
value, access to amenities, and life quality. A great location can make even a
modest home highly desirable. Therefore, incorporating location into
recommendations is essential for their effectiveness. We propose a geo-aware
embedding framework to address sparsity and spatial nuances in housing
recommendations on digital rental platforms. Our approach integrates an
hierarchical H3 grid at multiple levels into a two-tower neural architecture.
We compare our method with a traditional matrix factorization baseline and a
single-resolution variant using interaction data from our platform. Embedding
specific evaluation reveals richer and more balanced embedding representations,
while offline ranking simulations demonstrate a substantial uplift in
recommendation quality.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a geo-aware embedding framework for housing recommendations to address challenges in sparsity and spatial nuances.
AI.motivation: To improve housing recommendations by incorporating location, which plays a critical role in property value and user preferences.
AI.method: Proposed a two-tower neural architecture with hierarchical H3 grid integration, compared against traditional matrix factorization and single-resolution models.
AI.result: Achieved richer and more balanced embedding representations, with significant improvement in recommendation quality in offline simulations.
AI.conclusion: The geo-aware approach enhances housing recommendations by effectively addressing spatial and sparsity challenges, demonstrating its potential for digital rental platforms.

title: Emotional Text-To-Speech Based on Mutual-Information-Guided Emotion-Timbre Disentanglement
comment:
In Proceedings of the 17th Asia Pacific Signal and Information
  Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC 2025)
summary:
Current emotional Text-To-Speech (TTS) and style transfer methods rely on
reference encoders to control global style or emotion vectors, but do not
capture nuanced acoustic details of the reference speech. To this end, we
propose a novel emotional TTS method that enables fine-grained phoneme-level
emotion embedding prediction while disentangling intrinsic attributes of the
reference speech. The proposed method employs a style disentanglement method to
guide two feature extractors, reducing mutual information between timbre and
emotion features, and effectively separating distinct style components from the
reference speech. Experimental results demonstrate that our method outperforms
baseline TTS systems in generating natural and emotionally rich speech. This
work highlights the potential of disentangled and fine-grained representations
in advancing the quality and flexibility of emotional TTS systems.

AI.tldr: A novel emotional Text-To-Speech (TTS) method is proposed, focusing on fine-grained phoneme-level emotion embedding and disentangling style attributes.
AI.motivation: Current methods lack the ability to capture nuanced acoustic details of reference speech, limiting emotional and stylistic control.
AI.method: Introduces a style disentanglement technique combined with two feature extractors, reducing mutual information between timbre and emotion, enabling fine-grained emotion embedding prediction at the phoneme level.
AI.result: Experimental findings indicate that the proposed approach surpasses baseline systems in producing natural and emotionally rich speech.
AI.conclusion: Disentangled and detailed representation strategies hold promise for enhancing emotional TTS systems' quality and adaptability.

title: Secure Multi-Modal Data Fusion in Federated Digital Health Systems via MCP
summary:
Secure and interoperable integration of heterogeneous medical data remains a
grand challenge in digital health. Current federated learning (FL) frameworks
offer privacy-preserving model training but lack standardized mechanisms to
orchestrate multi-modal data fusion across distributed and resource-constrained
environments. This study introduces a novel framework that leverages the Model
Context Protocol (MCP) as an interoperability layer for secure, cross-agent
communication in multi-modal federated healthcare systems. The proposed
architecture unifies three pillars: (i) multi-modal feature alignment for
clinical imaging, electronic medical records, and wearable IoT data; (ii)
secure aggregation with differential privacy to protect patient-sensitive
updates; and (iii) energy-aware scheduling to mitigate dropouts in mobile
clients. By employing MCP as a schema-driven interface, the framework enables
adaptive orchestration of AI agents and toolchains while ensuring compliance
with privacy regulations. Experimental evaluation on benchmark datasets and
pilot clinical cohorts demonstrates up to 9.8\% improvement in diagnostic
accuracy compared with baseline FL, a 54\% reduction in client dropout rates,
and clinically acceptable privacy--utility trade-offs. These results highlight
MCP-enabled multi-modal fusion as a scalable and trustworthy pathway toward
equitable, next-generation federated health infrastructures.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a novel multi-modal federated learning framework using the Model Context Protocol (MCP) to enhance security, interoperability, and scalability in healthcare systems.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of secure and standardized mechanisms for multi-modal data integration in existing federated learning frameworks for healthcare.
AI.method: Combines multi-modal feature alignment, differential privacy for secure data aggregation, and energy-aware scheduling, leveraging MCP as an interoperability layer for distributed AI systems.
AI.result: Achieved up to 9.8% better diagnostic accuracy, 54% lower client dropout rates, and maintained a favorable privacy-utility balance in experimental evaluations.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework offers a scalable and trustworthy approach for enabling next-generation federated healthcare systems with improved security, interoperability, and diagnostic performance.

title: SingMOS-Pro: An Comprehensive Benchmark for Singing Quality Assessment
summary:
Singing voice generation progresses rapidly, yet evaluating singing quality
remains a critical challenge. Human subjective assessment, typically in the
form of listening tests, is costly and time consuming, while existing objective
metrics capture only limited perceptual aspects. In this work, we introduce
SingMOS-Pro, a dataset for automatic singing quality assessment. Building on
our preview version SingMOS, which provides only overall ratings, SingMOS-Pro
expands annotations of the additional part to include lyrics, melody, and
overall quality, offering broader coverage and greater diversity. The dataset
contains 7,981 singing clips generated by 41 models across 12 datasets,
spanning from early systems to recent advances. Each clip receives at least
five ratings from professional annotators, ensuring reliability and
consistency. Furthermore, we explore how to effectively utilize MOS data
annotated under different standards and benchmark several widely used
evaluation methods from related tasks on SingMOS-Pro, establishing strong
baselines and practical references for future research. The dataset can be
accessed at https://huggingface.co/datasets/TangRain/SingMOS-Pro.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SingMOS-Pro, a dataset for automatic singing voice quality evaluation, offering broader annotations and strong baselines for future research.
AI.motivation: Evaluating singing quality objectively is challenging due to limitations in human subjective listening tests and existing metrics.
AI.method: SingMOS-Pro expands on a prior dataset by including additional qualitative metrics (lyrics, melody, overall). Professional annotators rate 7,981 clips generated by a diverse range of models.
AI.result: The dataset provides reliable annotations and benchmarks for evaluation methods, enhancing the framework for objective singing quality assessment.
AI.conclusion: SingMOS-Pro establishes a solid foundation for automatic singing quality assessment, bridging gaps and supporting future innovations in the field.

title: Hybrid Predictive Modeling of Malaria Incidence in the Amhara Region, Ethiopia: Integrating Multi-Output Regression and Time-Series Forecasting
summary:
Malaria remains a major public health concern in Ethiopia, particularly in
the Amhara Region, where seasonal and unpredictable transmission patterns make
prevention and control challenging. Accurately forecasting malaria outbreaks is
essential for effective resource allocation and timely interventions. This
study proposes a hybrid predictive modeling framework that combines time-series
forecasting, multi-output regression, and conventional regression-based
prediction to forecast the incidence of malaria. Environmental variables, past
malaria case data, and demographic information from Amhara Region health
centers were used to train and validate the models. The multi-output regression
approach enables the simultaneous prediction of multiple outcomes, including
Plasmodium species-specific cases, temporal trends, and spatial variations,
whereas the hybrid framework captures both seasonal patterns and correlations
among predictors. The proposed model exhibits higher prediction accuracy than
single-method approaches, exposing hidden patterns and providing valuable
information to public health authorities. This study provides a valid and
repeatable malaria incidence prediction framework that can support
evidence-based decision-making, targeted interventions, and resource
optimization in endemic areas.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a hybrid predictive model to forecast malaria outbreaks in Ethiopia's Amhara Region, showing better accuracy compared to single-method approaches.
AI.motivation: Malaria in Ethiopia, particularly in the Amhara Region, has complex transmission patterns that make prevention and intervention difficult. Accurate outbreak forecasting is crucial for proper resource allocation and timely interventions.
AI.method: A hybrid predictive modeling framework combining time-series forecasting, multi-output regression, and conventional regression. The framework utilizes environmental variables, past malaria data, and demographic information from regional health centers.
AI.result: The proposed model outperformed single-method approaches, offering higher prediction accuracy and exposing hidden patterns in malaria transmission.
AI.conclusion: The study presents an effective framework for predicting malaria incidence, assisting public health authorities in evidence-based decision-making, resource optimization, and targeted interventions.

title: NGGAN: Noise Generation GAN Based on the Practical Measurement Dataset for Narrowband Powerline Communications
comment:
16 pages, 15 figures, 11 tables, and published in IEEE Transactions
  on Instrumentation and Measurement, Vol. 74, 2025
summary:
Capturing comprehensive statistics of nonperiodic asynchronous impulsive
noise is a critical issue in enhancing impulse noise processing for narrowband
powerline communication (NB-PLC) transceivers. However, existing mathematical
noise generative models capture only some of the characteristics of additive
noise. Therefore, we propose a generative adversarial network (GAN), called the
noise-generation GAN (NGGAN), that learns the complicated characteristics of
practically measured noise samples for data augmentation. To closely match the
statistics of complicated noise in NB-PLC systems, we measured the NB-PLC noise
via the analog coupling and bandpass filtering circuits of a commercial NB-PLC
modem to build a realistic dataset. Specifically, the NGGAN design approaches
based on the practically measured dataset are as follows: (i) we design the
length of input signals that the NGGAN model can fit to facilitate
cyclo-stationary noise generation. (ii) Wasserstein distance is used as a loss
function to enhance the similarity between the generated noise and the training
dataset and ensure that the sample diversity is sufficient for various
applications. (iii) To measure the similarity performance of the GAN-based
models based on mathematical and practically measured datasets, we perform
quantitative and qualitative analyses. The training datasets include (1) a
piecewise spectral cyclo-stationary Gaussian model (PSCGM), (2) a
frequency-shift (FRESH) filter, and (3) practical measurements from NB-PLC
systems. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed NGGAN trained using
waveform characteristics is closer to the practically measured dataset in terms
of the quality of the generated noise.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a novel generative adversarial network (GAN) model called NGGAN, designed to generate noise samples for narrowband powerline communication (NB-PLC) transceivers. The NGGAN model is trained on practically measured noise data, demonstrating improved quality in noise generation compared to existing models.
AI.motivation: Existing mathematical noise models capture only partial characteristics of additive noise, which results in limitations for NB-PLC transceivers. The authors aim to enhance noise processing capabilities by creating a model that learns and generates comprehensive noise statistics based on real measurements.
AI.method: The authors propose NGGAN, a GAN-based model that learns from practically measured NB-PLC noise. Key approaches include setting an input signal length tailored for cyclo-stationary noise generation, using Wasserstein distance for the loss function, and conducting both quantitative and qualitative analyses based on mathematical and measured datasets.
AI.result: Simulation results indicate that NGGAN surpasses traditional mathematical noise models, like a piecewise spectral cyclo-stationary Gaussian model (PSCGM) and frequency-shift (FRESH) filters, in matching the characteristics of noise measured in actual NB-PLC systems.
AI.conclusion: The NGGAN model effectively captures the complex characteristics of NB-PLC noise, offering enhanced data augmentation capabilities and improving the feasibility of studying and processing impulse noise in such systems.

title: Combining complex Langevin dynamics with score-based and energy-based diffusion models
summary:
Theories with a sign problem due to a complex action or Boltzmann weight can
sometimes be numerically solved using a stochastic process in the complexified
configuration space. However, the probability distribution effectively sampled
by this complex Langevin process is not known a priori and notoriously hard to
understand. In generative AI, diffusion models can learn distributions, or
their log derivatives, from data. We explore the ability of diffusion models to
learn the distributions sampled by a complex Langevin process, comparing
score-based and energy-based diffusion models, and speculate about possible
applications.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates leveraging diffusion models in generative AI to better understand distributions sampled by complex Langevin processes, particularly in theories with a sign problem.
AI.motivation: The study is motivated by the challenge of understanding the probability distributions associated with the complex Langevin process, which are difficult to determine and analyze a priori.
AI.method: The authors compare two types of diffusion models—score-based and energy-based—in their ability to learn distributions sampled by the complex Langevin process.
AI.result: The paper demonstrates how diffusion models can effectively learn these distributions and highlights their potential in tackling such complex problems.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion models offer a promising avenue for resolving challenges in studying probability distributions from complex Langevin processes, opening up new possibilities and applications.

title: FINCH: Financial Intelligence using Natural language for Contextualized SQL Handling
summary:
Text-to-SQL, the task of translating natural language questions into SQL
queries, has long been a central challenge in NLP. While progress has been
significant, applying it to the financial domain remains especially difficult
due to complex schema, domain-specific terminology, and high stakes of error.
Despite this, there is no dedicated large-scale financial dataset to advance
research, creating a critical gap. To address this, we introduce a curated
financial dataset (FINCH) comprising 292 tables and 75,725 natural language-SQL
pairs, enabling both fine-tuning and rigorous evaluation. Building on this
resource, we benchmark reasoning models and language models of varying scales,
providing a systematic analysis of their strengths and limitations in financial
Text-to-SQL tasks. Finally, we propose a finance-oriented evaluation metric
(FINCH Score) that captures nuances overlooked by existing measures, offering a
more faithful assessment of model performance.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces FINCH, a dataset specifically designed for financial Text-to-SQL tasks, and benchmarks different reasoning and language models using it, with the addition of a new evaluation metric called FINCH Score.
AI.motivation: The study aims to address the lack of a large-scale financial dataset for Text-to-SQL applications, which presents unique challenges due to the complex schema and high-stakes errors associated with the financial domain.
AI.method: Researchers created the FINCH dataset with 292 tables and 75,725 natural language-SQL pairs. They analyzed and benchmarked various models for their performance on financial Text-to-SQL tasks and introduced the FINCH Score evaluation metric.
AI.result: The authors showcased a systematic analysis of model strengths and limitations using the FINCH dataset, contributing important insights into the financial domain's Text-to-SQL challenges.
AI.conclusion: The FINCH dataset and FINCH Score provide critical tools for advancing research in financial Text-to-SQL applications, addressing existing gaps and paving the way for more reliable and domain-specific machine learning solutions.

title: Small is Sufficient: Reducing the World AI Energy Consumption Through Model Selection
summary:
The energy consumption and carbon footprint of Artificial Intelligence (AI)
have become critical concerns due to rising costs and environmental impacts. In
response, a new trend in green AI is emerging, shifting from the "bigger is
better" paradigm, which prioritizes large models, to "small is sufficient",
emphasizing energy sobriety through smaller, more efficient models.
  We explore how the AI community can adopt energy sobriety today by focusing
on model selection during inference. Model selection consists of choosing the
most appropriate model for a given task, a simple and readily applicable
method, unlike approaches requiring new hardware or architectures. Our
hypothesis is that, as in many industrial activities, marginal utility gains
decrease with increasing model size. Thus, applying model selection can
significantly reduce energy consumption while maintaining good utility for AI
inference.
  We conduct a systematic study of AI tasks, analyzing their popularity, model
size, and efficiency. We examine how the maturity of different tasks and model
adoption patterns impact the achievable energy savings, ranging from 1% to 98%
for different tasks. Our estimates indicate that applying model selection could
reduce AI energy consumption by 27.8%, saving 31.9 TWh worldwide in 2025 -
equivalent to the annual output of five nuclear power reactors.

AI.tldr: This paper advocates for shifting towards energy-efficient AI models to reduce energy consumption and carbon footprint, focusing on task-specific model selection during inference.
AI.motivation: Addressing the increasing energy consumption and environmental impact of scaling AI models under the 'bigger is better' paradigm by promoting a shift towards smaller, more efficient models.
AI.method: The study proposes task-specific model selection during inference, emphasizing its simplicity and immediate applicability without requiring new hardware or architectural changes.
AI.result: Energy savings through model selection are estimated between 1%-98% across tasks, with a potential global reduction in AI energy consumption of 27.8%, equating to 31.9 TWh savings by 2025.
AI.conclusion: Adopting task-specific model selection can significantly reduce energy usage and support sustainability goals in AI, offering an impactful and easy-to-implement alternative to current practices.

title: Learning to Play Multi-Follower Bayesian Stackelberg Games
summary:
In a multi-follower Bayesian Stackelberg game, a leader plays a mixed
strategy over $L$ actions to which $n\ge 1$ followers, each having one of $K$
possible private types, best respond. The leader's optimal strategy depends on
the distribution of the followers' private types. We study an online learning
version of this problem: a leader interacts for $T$ rounds with $n$ followers
with types sampled from an unknown distribution every round. The leader's goal
is to minimize regret, defined as the difference between the cumulative utility
of the optimal strategy and that of the actually chosen strategies. We design
learning algorithms for the leader under different feedback settings. Under
type feedback, where the leader observes the followers' types after each round,
we design algorithms that achieve $\mathcal O\big(\sqrt{\min\{L\log(nKA T), nK
\} \cdot T} \big)$ regret for independent type distributions and $\mathcal
O\big(\sqrt{\min\{L\log(nKA T), K^n \} \cdot T} \big)$ regret for general type
distributions. Interestingly, those bounds do not grow with $n$ at a polynomial
rate. Under action feedback, where the leader only observes the followers'
actions, we design algorithms with $\mathcal O( \min\{\sqrt{ n^L K^L A^{2L} L T
\log T}, K^n\sqrt{ T } \log T \} )$ regret. We also provide a lower bound of
$\Omega(\sqrt{\min\{L, nK\}T})$, almost matching the type-feedback upper
bounds.

AI.tldr: The paper tackles an online learning problem in multi-follower Bayesian Stackelberg games where a leader minimizes regret against followers with private types sampled from an unknown distribution. Different feedback settings are considered, with efficient algorithms developed for each.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of optimizing strategies in multi-follower Bayesian Stackelberg games, where the leader must adaptively learn to minimize regret without prior knowledge of the followers' type distribution.
AI.method: Algorithms were developed for two feedback settings: (1) Type feedback, where the followers' private types are observable to the leader, and (2) Action feedback, where only followers' actions are observable. Theoretical bounds on regret were derived for both cases.
AI.result: Under type feedback, regret bounds achieved are \(\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\min\{L\log(nKA T), nK \} \cdot T})\) for independent distributions and \(\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\min\{L\log(nKA T), K^n \} \cdot T})\) for general distributions. For action feedback, regret bounds are \(\mathcal{O}( \min\{\sqrt{ n^L K^L A^{2L} L T \log T}, K^n\sqrt{ T } \log T \} )\). A lower bound of \(\Omega(\sqrt{\min\{L, nK\}T})\) was also established.
AI.conclusion: The study presents near-optimal learning algorithms for the leader in multi-follower Bayesian Stackelberg games across varying feedback paradigms, providing insights into regret bounds and their dependency on game parameters.

title: HRTFformer: A Spatially-Aware Transformer for Personalized HRTF Upsampling in Immersive Audio Rendering
summary:
Personalized Head-Related Transfer Functions (HRTFs) are starting to be
introduced in many commercial immersive audio applications and are crucial for
realistic spatial audio rendering. However, one of the main hesitations
regarding their introduction is that creating personalized HRTFs is impractical
at scale due to the complexities of the HRTF measurement process. To mitigate
this drawback, HRTF spatial upsampling has been proposed with the aim of
reducing measurements required. While prior work has seen success with
different machine learning (ML) approaches, these models often struggle with
long-range spatial consistency and generalization at high upsampling factors.
In this paper, we propose a novel transformer-based architecture for HRTF
upsampling, leveraging the attention mechanism to better capture spatial
correlations across the HRTF sphere. Working in the spherical harmonic (SH)
domain, our model learns to reconstruct high-resolution HRTFs from sparse input
measurements with significantly improved accuracy. To enhance spatial
coherence, we introduce a neighbor dissimilarity loss that promotes magnitude
smoothness, yielding more realistic upsampling. We evaluate our method using
both perceptual localization models and objective spectral distortion metrics.
Experiments show that our model surpasses leading methods by a substantial
margin in generating realistic, high-fidelity HRTFs.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a transformer-based model for HRTF spatial upsampling, outperforming previous approaches in accurately reconstructing high-resolution HRTFs from sparse measurements.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the impracticality of measuring personalized HRTFs at scale and improve methods to efficiently generate high-resolution HRTFs, crucial for immersive spatial audio applications.
AI.method: A novel transformer-based architecture is proposed, leveraging attention mechanisms for spatial correlations in the HRTF sphere. The model operates in the spherical harmonic domain and employs a neighbor dissimilarity loss for improved spatial coherence.
AI.result: The proposed model achieved significant improvements in the accuracy and realism of upsampled HRTFs based on perceptual and objective spectral distortion evaluations, outperforming existing methods.
AI.conclusion: The transformer-based approach demonstrates a promising solution for scalable HRTF upsampling with enhanced spatial coherence and fidelity, contributing to advancements in immersive audio technologies.

title: Financial Stability Implications of Generative AI: Taming the Animal Spirits
summary:
This paper investigates the impact of the adoption of generative AI on
financial stability. We conduct laboratory-style experiments using large
language models to replicate classic studies on herd behavior in trading
decisions. Our results show that AI agents make more rational decisions than
humans, relying predominantly on private information over market trends.
Increased reliance on AI-powered trading advice could therefore potentially
lead to fewer asset price bubbles arising from animal spirits that trade by
following the herd. However, exploring variations in the experimental settings
reveals that AI agents can be induced to herd optimally when explicitly guided
to make profit-maximizing decisions. While optimal herding improves market
discipline, this behavior still carries potential implications for financial
stability. In other experimental variations, we show that AI agents are not
purely algorithmic, but have inherited some elements of human conditioning and
bias.

AI.tldr: The paper explores how generative AI impacts financial stability, finding that AI agents generally make rational trading decisions, reducing herd behavior but with noteworthy implications.
AI.motivation: To examine how generative AI adoption influences trading decisions and financial stability, focusing on rationality and herd behavior.
AI.method: Laboratory experiments using large language models replicate classic studies on trading herd behavior under various conditions.
AI.result: AI agents favor private information over market trends, reducing asset bubbles from irrational herd behavior, but can also demonstrate guided optimal herding.
AI.conclusion: AI trading advice potentially stabilizes markets by lowering animal spirits-driven bubbles, yet inherits human biases and raises financial stability concerns depending on experimental settings.

title: Exploring Resolution-Wise Shared Attention in Hybrid Mamba-U-Nets for Improved Cross-Corpus Speech Enhancement
comment: Submitted to IEEE for possible publication
summary:
Recent advances in speech enhancement have shown that models combining Mamba
and attention mechanisms yield superior cross-corpus generalization
performance. At the same time, integrating Mamba in a U-Net structure has
yielded state-of-the-art enhancement performance, while reducing both model
size and computational complexity. Inspired by these insights, we propose
RWSA-MambaUNet, a novel and efficient hybrid model combining Mamba and
multi-head attention in a U-Net structure for improved cross-corpus
performance. Resolution-wise shared attention (RWSA) refers to layerwise
attention-sharing across corresponding time- and frequency resolutions. Our
best-performing RWSA-MambaUNet model achieves state-of-the-art generalization
performance on two out-of-domain test sets. Notably, our smallest model
surpasses all baselines on the out-of-domain DNS 2020 test set in terms of
PESQ, SSNR, and ESTOI, and on the out-of-domain EARS-WHAM_v2 test set in terms
of SSNR, ESTOI, and SI-SDR, while using less than half the model parameters and
a fraction of the FLOPs.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces RWSA-MambaUNet, a hybrid speech enhancement model integrating Mamba and multi-head attention within a U-Net structure. It outperforms existing models on out-of-domain test sets with superior efficiency.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of achieving superior generalization performance across diverse speech datasets while minimizing model complexity and computational demands.
AI.method: Proposed a novel RWSA-MambaUNet model that uses Mamba and multi-head attention mechanisms within a U-Net structure. Resolution-wise shared attention (RWSA) is employed for layerwise attention-sharing across various time and frequency resolutions.
AI.result: RWSA-MambaUNet achieves state-of-the-art performance on two out-of-domain speech enhancement test sets, surpassing baselines in PESQ, SSNR, ESTOI, and SI-SDR metrics, while being highly efficient in terms of model parameters and FLOPs.
AI.conclusion: The hybrid model successfully combines advanced mechanisms to deliver enhanced speech quality and robust generalization capabilities while reducing computational costs, showcasing a promising direction for efficient speech enhancement systems.

title: Comparative Field Deployment of Reinforcement Learning and Model Predictive Control for Residential HVAC
comment: 27 pages, 11 figures, 4 tables. Under review for Applied Energy
summary:
Advanced control strategies like Model Predictive Control (MPC) offer
significant energy savings for HVAC systems but often require substantial
engineering effort, limiting scalability. Reinforcement Learning (RL) promises
greater automation and adaptability, yet its practical application in
real-world residential settings remains largely undemonstrated, facing
challenges related to safety, interpretability, and sample efficiency. To
investigate these practical issues, we performed a direct comparison of an MPC
and a model-based RL controller, with each controller deployed for a one-month
period in an occupied house with a heat pump system in West Lafayette, Indiana.
This investigation aimed to explore scalability of the chosen RL and MPC
implementations while ensuring safety and comparability. The advanced
controllers were evaluated against each other and against the existing
controller. RL achieved substantial energy savings (22\% relative to the
existing controller), slightly exceeding MPC's savings (20\%), albeit with
modestly higher occupant discomfort. However, when energy savings were
normalized for the level of comfort provided, MPC demonstrated superior
performance. This study's empirical results show that while RL reduces
engineering overhead, it introduces practical trade-offs in model accuracy and
operational robustness. The key lessons learned concern the difficulties of
safe controller initialization, navigating the mismatch between control actions
and their practical implementation, and maintaining the integrity of online
learning in a live environment. These insights pinpoint the essential research
directions needed to advance RL from a promising concept to a truly scalable
HVAC control solution.

AI.tldr: This paper compares Model Predictive Control (MPC) and Reinforcement Learning (RL) for HVAC systems in a real-world residential setting, evaluating their energy-saving performance and scalability.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the scalability and practical application challenges of advanced HVAC control strategies by comparing MPC and RL, particularly focusing on RL's potential for greater automation and adaptability.
AI.method: The authors performed a one-month-long, real-world empirical comparison of MPC and a model-based RL controller in an occupied house with a heat pump system. They assessed energy savings, scalability, and occupant comfort while ensuring operational safety.
AI.result: The study found that RL achieved 22% energy savings, slightly exceeding MPC's 20%. However, when normalized for comfort, MPC outperformed RL. RL demonstrated reduced engineering overhead but faced practical trade-offs in robustness and accuracy.
AI.conclusion: RL shows promise for automation but currently faces challenges such as safety, initialization, and maintaining learning integrity. The paper identifies critical research directions to make RL a scalable HVAC control solution.

title: The Current State of AI Bias Bounties: An Overview of Existing Programmes and Research
comment:
6,227 words (18 pages, from abstract to appendix), one figure, one
  table, and an appendix with an additional table
summary:
Current bias evaluation methods rarely engage with communities impacted by AI
systems. Inspired by bug bounties, bias bounties have been proposed as a
reward-based method that involves communities in AI bias detection by asking
users of AI systems to report biases they encounter when interacting with such
systems. In the absence of a state-of-the-art review, this survey aimed to
identify and analyse existing AI bias bounty programmes and to present academic
literature on bias bounties. Google, Google Scholar, PhilPapers, and IEEE
Xplore were searched, and five bias bounty programmes, as well as five research
publications, were identified. All bias bounties were organised by U.S.-based
organisations as time-limited contests, with public participation in four
programmes and prize pools ranging from 7,000 to 24,000 USD. The five research
publications included a report on the application of bug bounties to
algorithmic harms, an article addressing Twitter's bias bounty, a proposal for
bias bounties as an institutional mechanism to increase AI scrutiny, a workshop
discussing bias bounties from queer perspectives, and an algorithmic framework
for bias bounties. We argue that reducing the technical requirements to enter
bounty programmes is important to include those without coding experience.
Given the limited adoption of bias bounties, future efforts should explore the
transferability of the best practices from bug bounties and examine how such
programmes can be designed to be sensitive to underrepresented groups while
lowering adoption barriers for organisations.

AI.tldr: Bias bounties, inspired by bug bounties, involve communities in identifying AI biases through reward-based methods. This survey reviews five existing programs and academic discussions, urging more inclusivity and lowering barriers for broader adoption.
AI.motivation: Bias evaluation in AI systems often excludes impacted communities. Inspired by successful bug bounties, bias bounties aim to engage users in detecting and reporting AI biases.
AI.method: The study reviewed five existing bias bounty programs and five academic publications by searching platforms like Google, Google Scholar, PhilPapers, and IEEE Xplore.
AI.result: All identified bias bounties were time-limited, U.S.-based contests, with varying public participation and prize pools. Reviewed academic work explored practical, critical, and theoretical aspects of bias bounties.
AI.conclusion: The paper advocates for reducing technical barriers to make bias bounties accessible to non-programmers and suggests learning from bug bounties to improve inclusivity and organizational adoption.

title: Unlocking Symbol-Level Precoding Efficiency Through Tensor Equivariant Neural Network
comment: This work has been submitted to the IEEE for possible publication
summary:
Although symbol-level precoding (SLP) based on constructive interference (CI)
exploitation offers performance gains, its high complexity remains a
bottleneck. This paper addresses this challenge with an end-to-end deep
learning (DL) framework with low inference complexity that leverages the
structure of the optimal SLP solution in the closed-form and its inherent
tensor equivariance (TE), where TE denotes that a permutation of the input
induces the corresponding permutation of the output. Building upon the
computationally efficient model-based formulations, as well as their known
closed-form solutions, we analyze their relationship with linear precoding (LP)
and investigate the corresponding optimality condition. We then construct a
mapping from the problem formulation to the solution and prove its TE, based on
which the designed networks reveal a specific parameter-sharing pattern that
delivers low computational complexity and strong generalization. Leveraging
these, we propose the backbone of the framework with an attention-based TE
module, achieving linear computational complexity. Furthermore, we demonstrate
that such a framework is also applicable to imperfect CSI scenarios, where we
design a TE-based network to map the CSI, statistics, and symbols to auxiliary
variables. Simulation results show that the proposed framework captures
substantial performance gains of optimal SLP, while achieving an approximately
80-times speedup over conventional methods and maintaining strong
generalization across user numbers and symbol block lengths.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a computationally efficient deep learning framework for symbol-level precoding (SLP) that leverages tensor equivariance to achieve substantial performance gains and speedup.
AI.motivation: To address the high computational complexity of optimal constructive interference-based symbol-level precoding (SLP).
AI.method: The authors propose a deep learning framework that integrates tensor equivariance and attention-based modules to map input data to solutions efficiently. The framework accounts for known closed-form solutions and their relationship to linear precoding.
AI.result: The framework achieves linear computational complexity, adaptability to imperfect CSI scenarios, and provides an 80x speedup over traditional methods while maintaining strong generalization across varying user numbers and symbol lengths.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach offers a practical and efficient way to leverage the performance benefits of optimal SLP without its computational challenges.

title: CardioRAG: A Retrieval-Augmented Generation Framework for Multimodal Chagas Disease Detection
comment:
4 pages, 2 figures. Accepted for oral presentation at the 52nd
  international Computing in Cardiology Conference (CinC2025)
summary:
Chagas disease affects nearly 6 million people worldwide, with Chagas
cardiomyopathy representing its most severe complication. In regions where
serological testing capacity is limited, AI-enhanced electrocardiogram (ECG)
screening provides a critical diagnostic alternative. However, existing machine
learning approaches face challenges such as limited accuracy, reliance on large
labeled datasets, and more importantly, weak integration with evidence-based
clinical diagnostic indicators. We propose a retrieval-augmented generation
framework, CardioRAG, integrating large language models with interpretable
ECG-based clinical features, including right bundle branch block, left anterior
fascicular block, and heart rate variability metrics. The framework uses
variational autoencoder-learned representations for semantic case retrieval,
providing contextual cases to guide clinical reasoning. Evaluation demonstrated
high recall performance of 89.80%, with a maximum F1 score of 0.68 for
effective identification of positive cases requiring prioritized serological
testing. CardioRAG provides an interpretable, clinical evidence-based approach
particularly valuable for resource-limited settings, demonstrating a pathway
for embedding clinical indicators into trustworthy medical AI systems.

AI.tldr: The research presents CardioRAG, a machine learning framework integrating clinical reasoning with AI-enhanced ECG-based features for improved Chagas disease diagnosis.
AI.motivation: Current diagnostic methods for Chagas disease cardiomyopathy in resource-limited areas are hindered by limited accuracy and lack of integration with medical indicators.
AI.method: CardioRAG combines large language models, interpretable ECG-based clinical features, and variational autoencoders for semantic case retrieval and reasoning.
AI.result: CardioRAG achieved 89.80% recall and a maximum F1 score of 0.68 for identifying positive cases needing serological testing.
AI.conclusion: CardioRAG offers a trustworthy AI-based diagnostic tool by embedding clinical indicators, addressing accuracy, interpretability, and resource limitations.

title: BioinfoMCP: A Unified Platform Enabling MCP Interfaces in Agentic Bioinformatics
summary:
Bioinformatics tools are essential for complex computational biology tasks,
yet their integration with emerging AI-agent frameworks is hindered by
incompatible interfaces, heterogeneous input-output formats, and inconsistent
parameter conventions. The Model Context Protocol (MCP) provides a standardized
framework for tool-AI communication, but manually converting hundreds of
existing and rapidly growing specialized bioinformatics tools into
MCP-compliant servers is labor-intensive and unsustainable. Here, we present
BioinfoMCP, a unified platform comprising two components: BioinfoMCP Converter,
which automatically generates robust MCP servers from tool documentation using
large language models, and BioinfoMCP Benchmark, which systematically validates
the reliability and versatility of converted tools across diverse computational
tasks. We present a platform of 38 MCP-converted bioinformatics tools,
extensively validated to show that 94.7% successfully executed complex
workflows across three widely used AI-agent platforms. By removing technical
barriers to AI automation, BioinfoMCP enables natural-language interaction with
sophisticated bioinformatics analyses without requiring extensive programming
expertise, offering a scalable path to intelligent, interoperable computational
biology.

AI.tldr: BioinfoMCP is a platform that automates the conversion of bioinformatics tools into AI-compatible servers and validates their performance, achieving 94.7% success in diverse workflows.
AI.motivation: The integration of bioinformatics tools with AI-agent frameworks is challenging due to incompatible interfaces, variable data formats, and different parameter standards.
AI.method: Developed a platform called BioinfoMCP, consisting of two components: an automated converter using large language models to create MCP-compliant servers and a benchmark system to validate these servers.
AI.result: 38 bioinformatics tools were successfully converted and extensively validated, with 94.7% demonstrating effective integration into AI-agent platforms for complex workflows.
AI.conclusion: BioinfoMCP significantly reduces technical barriers for integrating bioinformatics tools with AI, enabling scalable and accessible computational biology workflows driven by natural language interaction.

title: How to Find Fantastic Papers: Self-Rankings as a Powerful Predictor of Scientific Impact Beyond Peer Review
summary:
Peer review in academic research aims not only to ensure factual correctness
but also to identify work of high scientific potential that can shape future
research directions. This task is especially critical in fast-moving fields
such as artificial intelligence (AI), yet it has become increasingly difficult
given the rapid growth of submissions. In this paper, we investigate an
underexplored measure for identifying high-impact research: authors' own
rankings of their multiple submissions to the same AI conference. Grounded in
game-theoretic reasoning, we hypothesize that self-rankings are informative
because authors possess unique understanding of their work's conceptual depth
and long-term promise. To test this hypothesis, we conducted a large-scale
experiment at a leading AI conference, where 1,342 researchers self-ranked
their 2,592 submissions by perceived quality. Tracking outcomes over more than
a year, we found that papers ranked highest by their authors received twice as
many citations as their lowest-ranked counterparts; self-rankings were
especially effective at identifying highly cited papers (those with over 150
citations). Moreover, we showed that self-rankings outperformed peer review
scores in predicting future citation counts. Our results remained robust after
accounting for confounders such as preprint posting time and self-citations.
Together, these findings demonstrate that authors' self-rankings provide a
reliable and valuable complement to peer review for identifying and elevating
high-impact research in AI.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how authors' self-ranking of their conference submissions can serve as a reliable tool for identifying high-impact research in AI.
AI.motivation: The rapid growth in submissions in fast-evolving fields like AI has made it increasingly challenging for peer reviews to identify high-impact research. Authors' own understanding of their work's depth and potential could help address this issue.
AI.method: The authors conducted a large-scale experiment where 1,342 researchers self-ranked their 2,592 submissions to a leading AI conference. They tracked citation outcomes for over a year and controlled for confounding factors such as preprint posting time and self-citations.
AI.result: The papers ranked highest by authors received twice as many citations as their lowest-ranked counterparts. Self-ranking was superior to peer review scores in predicting future citation counts, offering robust results even after accounting for confounders.
AI.conclusion: Authors' self-rankings are a reliable and valuable complement to peer review, potentially enhancing the identification and elevation of impactful research in the AI field.

title: Human-Robo-advisor collaboration in decision-making: Evidence from a multiphase mixed methods experimental study
summary:
Robo-advisors (RAs) are cost-effective, bias-resistant alternatives to human
financial advisors, yet adoption remains limited. While prior research has
examined user interactions with RAs, less is known about how individuals
interpret RA roles and integrate their advice into decision-making. To address
this gap, this study employs a multiphase mixed methods design integrating a
behavioral experiment (N = 334), thematic analysis, and follow-up quantitative
testing. Findings suggest that people tend to rely on RAs, with reliance shaped
by information about RA performance and the framing of advice as gains or
losses. Thematic analysis reveals three RA roles in decision-making and four
user types, each reflecting distinct patterns of advice integration. In
addition, a 2 x 2 typology categorizes antecedents of acceptance into enablers
and inhibitors at both the individual and algorithmic levels. By combining
behavioral, interpretive, and confirmatory evidence, this study advances
understanding of human-RA collaboration and provides actionable insights for
designing more trustworthy and adaptive RA systems.

AI.tldr: Robo-advisors (RAs) are effective alternatives to human financial advisors, but adoption remains limited. This study explores how users interpret their roles and integrate their advice into decision-making.
AI.motivation: To understand the limited adoption of robo-advisors despite their advantages over human advisors, and to explore how users interpret their roles and advice.
AI.method: A mixed methods approach combining a behavioral experiment with 334 participants, thematic analysis, and follow-up quantitative testing.
AI.result: People tend to rely on RAs, influenced by performance information and advice framing. Three RA roles and four user types were identified, alongside a 2x2 typology of acceptance factors.
AI.conclusion: The study enhances comprehension of human-RAs collaboration, offering actionable recommendations for designing trustworthy and adaptive robo-advisors.

title: Evaluating the Robustness of a Production Malware Detection System to Transferable Adversarial Attacks
summary:
As deep learning models become widely deployed as components within larger
production systems, their individual shortcomings can create system-level
vulnerabilities with real-world impact. This paper studies how adversarial
attacks targeting an ML component can degrade or bypass an entire
production-grade malware detection system, performing a case study analysis of
Gmail's pipeline where file-type identification relies on a ML model.
  The malware detection pipeline in use by Gmail contains a machine learning
model that routes each potential malware sample to a specialized malware
classifier to improve accuracy and performance. This model, called Magika, has
been open sourced. By designing adversarial examples that fool Magika, we can
cause the production malware service to incorrectly route malware to an
unsuitable malware detector thereby increasing our chance of evading detection.
Specifically, by changing just 13 bytes of a malware sample, we can
successfully evade Magika in 90% of cases and thereby allow us to send malware
files over Gmail. We then turn our attention to defenses, and develop an
approach to mitigate the severity of these types of attacks. For our defended
production model, a highly resourced adversary requires 50 bytes to achieve
just a 20% attack success rate. We implement this defense, and, thanks to a
collaboration with Google engineers, it has already been deployed in production
for the Gmail classifier.

AI.tldr: Adversarial attacks on Gmail's ML-based malware detection system can significantly degrade detection. Researchers proposed defenses, reducing attack success and improving robustness.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to explore vulnerabilities in ML-powered production systems, particularly focusing on Gmail's malware detection system, and to assess the real-world impact of adversarial attacks on such systems.
AI.method: The study investigates adversarial attacks on Gmail's malware detection pipeline, specifically targeting its ML component named Magika. Researchers created adversarial examples by altering malware samples to fool Magika into routing files incorrectly.
AI.result: The study found that by changing just 13 bytes in a malware sample, attackers could evade Magika in 90% of cases and bypass the malware detection system. After implementing enhanced defenses, only 20% success rate was achieved even by adversaries altering 50 bytes.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that adversarial attacks present significant risks to production systems, but these can be mitigated effectively by implementing defenses like those developed in the study, which have already been integrated into Gmail's classifier.

title: Comparing Contrastive and Triplet Loss in Audio-Visual Embedding: Intra-Class Variance and Greediness Analysis
summary:
Contrastive loss and triplet loss are widely used objectives in deep metric
learning, yet their effects on representation quality remain insufficiently
understood. We present a theoretical and empirical comparison of these losses,
focusing on intra- and inter-class variance and optimization behavior (e.g.,
greedy updates). Through task-specific experiments with consistent settings on
synthetic data and real datasets-MNIST, CIFAR-10-it is shown that triplet loss
preserves greater variance within and across classes, supporting finer-grained
distinctions in the learned representations. In contrast, contrastive loss
tends to compact intra-class embeddings, which may obscure subtle semantic
differences. To better understand their optimization dynamics, By examining
loss-decay rate, active ratio, and gradient norm, we find that contrastive loss
drives many small updates early on, while triplet loss produces fewer but
stronger updates that sustain learning on hard examples. Finally, across both
classification and retrieval tasks on MNIST, CIFAR-10, CUB-200, and CARS196
datasets, our results consistently show that triplet loss yields superior
performance, which suggests using triplet loss for detail retention and
hard-sample focus, and contrastive loss for smoother, broad-based embedding
refinement.

AI.tldr: The paper compares contrastive and triplet loss in deep metric learning across theoretical and empirical aspects, showing triplet loss better supports detailed representation and hard-sample focus, while contrastive loss favors smoother embeddings.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to clarify the differences and effects of contrastive loss and triplet loss in deep metric learning, as their impact on representation quality is not well understood.
AI.method: The authors conduct task-specific experiments with synthetic and real datasets (MNIST, CIFAR-10, CUB-200, CARS196), evaluating intra-/inter-class variance, loss-decay rates, active ratios, and gradient norms to explore the optimization behavior of each loss.
AI.result: Triplet loss shows greater variance preservation within and across classes and produces fewer but stronger updates, improving detail retention and handling of hard examples. Contrastive loss favors compact intra-class embeddings but may obscure fine semantic distinctions.
AI.conclusion: Triplet loss is recommended for tasks requiring detail retention and focus on hard examples, while contrastive loss is better suited for smooth and generalized embedding refinement.

title: Go witheFlow: Real-time Emotion Driven Audio Effects Modulation
comment: Accepted at NeurIPS Creative AI Track 2025: Humanity
summary:
Music performance is a distinctly human activity, intrinsically linked to the
